snippet.textDisplay: I think there's a bit too much cognitive dissonance here. The people pissed enough to "boycott" aren't necessarily the same people buying the game anyway. A lot are, no doubt. But the amount of vocal people with principles is always tiny, compared to the massive amount of plebs who will just buy anything that looks moderately interesting.

snippet.textDisplay:
A friendly reminder that what happens on the internet is not only not real, but has zero impact on reality or the day to day life of people, businesses or politics. Twitter can be as angry as it wants to be over whatever its decides, but that doesn't translate even a tiny bit to anything tangible in the real world. You can't tweet a politician out of office, you can't upvote to bankrupt a business, and you can change the world with an internet petition.


Its also a healthy remind that the real world is not represented by the internet, a giant gaming subreddit full of angry customers is meaningless because maybe 1% of them are actually angry, and they are only 1% of 1% of the people who matter, IE: the actual paying customers, who don't visit forums or reddit or watch youtube videos over a pokemon game. They buy it because its pokemon and that is that and they don't care and they aren't listening to you, you don't matter even a fraction of a percent to their lives.

snippet.textDisplay:
To be clear, I have not supported Blizzard one, single time since the HK incident. I refunded/canceled pre-order of WC3 months ago and have removed all software from my PC.
As much as I wanted Pokemon Sword/Shield, I resisted because of Dexit, and now I'm glad I didn't due to the "expansions" they're going to release for a premium.
I still do not own any version of Call of Duty newer than the first Modern Warfare due to the dedicated server controversy and all the DLC/pre-order shenanigans.

I've done the same to other developers as well.

Have a fucking spine people. You're not missing out, there's so much more out there.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ah, I think I see wherein the problem lies.

To say that you're boycotting something is not the idea. To boycott, you need not say anything. Boycotting rests on not benefiting financially the party you intend to boycott. So if you want to boycott a gaming company, you are to not, I repeat, to NOT buy their game(s).

Hope that clears things up a bit.
snippet.textOriginal:
Ah, I think I see wherein the problem lies.

To say that you're boycotting something is not the idea. To boycott, you need not say anything. Boycotting rests on not benefiting financially the party you intend to boycott. So if you want to boycott a gaming company, you are to not, I repeat, to NOT buy their game(s).

Hope that clears things up a bit.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem is gaming communities are too separated and segmented by their nature.  As much as we can brew up a storm when something goes down that we don't like, there's usually a much larger multitude of gamers that simply can't be assed to do anything.  And that's fine.  It's like in politics, it affects everyone who lives in a country, but a majority of people are not full all-in gung-ho about getting their political point across or even reading deep enough into the system to do so.  Some people just want to live in reasonable comfort in their house in the country they're an honest upright citizen of.  Some gamers just want to pop in a game every now and again and don't care to see the noise unless it goes so far as to swarm right in their face.  That's why game boycotts will rarely work, if ever, and if they do it's not for very long, and I can liken that factor to politics as well but I digress.

snippet.textDisplay:
Gamers: Spyro Reignited has seperate downloads, CTR shoehorned microtransactions, B3 had a crackdown from 2K & Horny Bitchturd is scum, Astral Chain is Switch exclusive, the Switch is a joke full of ports & remasters, MK11 full of SJW cringe retcon propaganda, pre-orders full of shit, eShop full of shovelware, Sony censor up the ass, retro plug n plays are scams, abusive DLC practices suck & so do season passes & enough nostalgia pandering already! Gamers rise up!

Also gamers: Rose up to buy them anyway. By the millions.

Gamers as well: Get pissed that they worked & companies got away with it when they themselves spent their hard earned cash on them out of bile fascination, enticing pre-orders, no other option & sales that made them go "Heh, why not?".

Gamers on the side: We are the most oppressed group of people.

Pirates: Do what you want 'cause a pirate is free, you are a pi- Wait, how do you do that exactly? By not spamming this meme? Oh.

They walk the walk, but can't talk the talk because either they don't know how or think both are synonymous. Suppose Battlefront 2 was just lightning in a bottle. You guys remember Adam Sandler? He faced similar scorn, but people flocked to his films anyway, including his detractors. When you dislike something very much, keep your fucking word intact. No one else will do it for you, but you. Especially you.

snippet.textDisplay: Another example of people's dissatisfaction resulting in poor sales - Kind of the opposite of Battlefront 2. No-one talked about boycotting Colour Splash. It wasn't exactly controversial, either, just "Oh. It looks like they're continuing down the direction I didn't like with last one. Shame., and sales... Well if Video Game Sales Wiki is to be believed, it sold less than 200k, sales figures that not even being on the Wii U in 2016 can explain.

snippet.textDisplay: Personally I'm not such a fan of the games usually aimed for children, so the examples in the video were kinda unknown to me, but what about what's going on right now with Blizzard? WC3 Reforged flopped hard due to backlash, D3 also suffered from something similar, TW Rome 2 was a massive failure at launch, I don't know if it made much money at that time, did it? But I know Total War Thrones of Britannia didn't do well at all, same for Paradox' Imperator, as far as I know gamer don't have a bad track record at all.

snippet.textDisplay: I think boycotts fail is because they get stirred up before something hits the market - then people forget after launch... or they get stirred out after release, at which point it's already too late.
